												X3TC, for all you former EVE players that want basically a PvE version of Eve, this fits the bill nicely. I personally spent two years playing EVE and stopped back in 2013 as it took too much time. A few things are different, however it has a good size scope and has alot of tasks / things to do within the universe. Trade, build, fight, explore, etc. For those not familiar with EVE, this is a good space theme game that's a big sandbox, Steep learning curve. As with EVE, there is no real direction to go at first. You have to find your way about. Recommdation for anyone who hasn't played to watch a few youtube videos and read a few posts on the forums, etc. I've only played 15-20 hours (some offline) and have barely scratched the surface. Just mapping out the universe is time consuming. I can see that I'll be playing this one for a while.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												If you're looking for an open universe space game that lets you do what you want, this is it. However, if you're somebody that doesn't have the patience to learn practically everything by yourself, I would stray away. I took on the infamous "learning curve" this game has and I'm glad I did. I didn't think learning a game could actually frustrate me, but when I did learn, I started to have a lot of fun. There are very few space sandbox games that let you have this amount of control.What little of a tutorial this game has makes up for it in variety and content. You can approach success in space by trading or by working for the military. You'll start out with a small spacecraft with hardly any weaponry or cargo space and are set in a galaxy with many avenues of approach. Your only obstacle is your ambition. 6 hours later of learning and I now have 3 trading ships in my fleet, including two extra large tankers which I use to transport energy cells from solar power facilities to space stations that need them. Almost every sector without a solar power facility needs these cells to operate and is a quick way to gain a fortune to expand your fleet and your success in being a merchant.As mentioned earlier, you can also progress by working for the military or being a mercenary. The game starts you out with very little direction for this, but eventually you will find there is plenty of work to be done in the form of stations and military outposts looking for people to hire. Completing these jobs will earn you recoignition for your status as well as credits to spend on your ship or fleet.In the end you don't have to do any of this, you are free to explore where ever you like as far as you like, attack anybody you want, trade with anybody you want, settle with any species you want. And I'm promised that's not the end of it. I'm very excited to really dig into this game on a day I don't have to work, I look forward to the expansions of everyones space empire, should they choose to purchase this game.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This is a good example of needing a third option between recommend and not recommending.Everything in this game I should like, the exploration, the building an empire, and space combat. I can easily see someone sinking hundreds of hours into this game. Why haven't I then? Because it's boring as ♥♥♥♥.If you want a near realistic space sim, this is for you. Space is filled with a lot of nothing and there's a lot of nothing to do while flying between two destinations. I gave up on this game when I realized that I wanted the built in time speed increasing device to go FASTER than the maxium setting of (I think) 100x normal speed. The game gives you a built in mechanic to speed things up. I think that should be enough to say what's happening in this game.On the flip side, if you're doing something else and have this running in the background and look in on it now and again, this might be right up your alley. The game has massive potential, it's a shame I can't get past the slow pace of it to enjoy it.This is definitely a maybe game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Graphics may not be cutting edge, but you won't even notice.  Everything looks fantastic, especially with a certain mod installed that rebalances the entire game and adds a ton of stuff. The sound is ... well, it's spacey.  The ships make cool ship sounds, the weapons sound good.. kinda like weapons.  The music I really love, ambient and beautiful, usualy.  But action packed when you stir♥♥♥♥♥♥up.The gameplay is great - but do yourself a favor and install the mod I mention below, it adds a great deal of content and forces you to strategize a bit.. it makes the universe a lot more dangerous, too.I can't recommend this game enough.  It's not nearly as hard to get into as people make it sound.  They're just being complainy and have that disorder that is the reason why commercials and movies have to  flash to a different scene every 5 seconds and use bright colors to keep the viewers from wandering aimlessly away from the TV and off a cliff or something stupid like that without realizing what they're doing..  You know, that's goldfish level attention span.... just saying.  I guess what I mean is, they're only the big HALO and COD fans. And they suck, right?I installed the XRM mod... adds a whole lot more to an already massive game.  Very good.  Makes a lot more random and dangerous encounters with different factions. - I worked my way up till I hadl ike 9 trade ships and I did a few taxi missions and then i started buying fighters...  then I bought a couple of these little military transports (like a small carrier.. holds 4 ships and has a couple turrets... im no superpower ...yet) and I had the most awesome battle.  I jumped into some sector because I wanted to buy a bunch of missiles for my fighters and I ran into 2 of these Xenon corvettes and a few fighter's with them.   It turned into a big flashy battle and I completely mopped the floor with the bastages.   Even though I didn't have anything as big as a corvette myself, I deployed all my fighters and got into my Eclipse prototype ship and shot them all down.  In the end, the fighter I was flying was the only one that got really badly damaged and I didn't even lose one ship...  a little repairing to do, but hey... that was one of the most badass video game moments I've had in a very long time.  Even the early stages of my character where I was trading and playing the taxi driver (you can do anything you want... though) I was having a lot of fun.  I was looking for new sectors to trade in and new goods and I came across a sector called The Vault, and there was a Khaak destroyer and two frigates and they destroyed pretty much everything in the sector.. ultimately I had to run but I watched them take down wave after wave of defenses but they pretty much destroyed every station in that entire sector...  that = sweet.Buy this game... play this game...  it's so good I actually♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants, really.  And that's just when I think about playing it.. when I actually play... wow.   Do yourself a favor and download the amazing XRM mod, it adds so much depth and replayability, not that the game didn't already have this... but who doesn't like even more weapons, ships, customization, strategy and battles?  Pansies, that's who.  Are you a pansy?   Play the damn game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												I think you need only see my hours played for my opinion of this game. It took a huge effort by the community and devs to fix a great deal of issues at the start, but I've got to say this will remain in my favourite games list forever. Its a mindnumbingly difficult game to wrap your head around at first, but when you do you'll be rewarded with a damn good, persistent economic management sim alongside a beautiful space simulator (with plenty of dogfighting). It took months (partially due to a break, and partially due to a missing save (my fault completely) to get myself up to the point I got my first Carrier-class ship, and it was a beautiful moment watching a full fighter wing swarm and destroy another capital. The best selling point being you can sit back in your mammoth of a ship, or join the fight in a fighter (and these can be anything from nippy scouts, to heavy damage-soakers (and that's still not mentioning the myriad of Escort-class ships that bridge the gap between fighters and capitals.) Basically, if it flies, you can fly it.It is prohibitively slow at first, guides can help with this, and I seriously recommend modding in the late game, both for added features, and tweaking the game to suit you better (easier/harder combat, more enemy ships/greater frequency of huge ships) anyway I could go on, but I can guarantee if the above sounds like your sort of thing you'll get your money's worth and then some.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2012
												One of the biggest brothers in the trading and economic simulation genres, X3 Terran Conflict is, in my opinion, the go-to-game in the series over the vanilla X3 and Albion Prelude flavors (this is being written prior to the release of Reuinion). X3 is a game that will worm its way into the hearts of those who enjoy the RPG mechanic of starting out small and building yourself up. No green slimes will be slain, though. In this game you'll be starting out in a modest little space fighter or freighter and working your way into power and prosperity through combat, trade, or a mix of the two (salvaging gear from the strife of others). While combat was fun, and shouldn't dissapoint anyone coming from the Freespace school of gaming, I found trading and fleet management to be the most enjoyable and challenging parts of the game. X3's logistics, economy, and trading mechanics are as complex as they are fun, and a wonderful reward for those willing to brave the learning curve.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2012
												This game is freaking huge; it has the kind of scope and scale that you very rarely see in any game. You are given the option to effectively start with the space equivelent of a backpack and a shed, from which you can work your way up to owning an enormous fleet (and when i say enormous, i mean both numerous ships AND proportionally vast construction - there are ships so large they can't actually dock with any stations because they'd crush it!) entire sectors of space filled with your supply stations and factories, able to smash entire sectors into submission with brute force or starve them into poverty with strategic cordons of ships to block trade routes.HOWEVER - This. All. Takes. Time. Alot of time! Be warned: if you choose the slowest start it could be a good 30hours or so before you can even afford to buy another ship. This is not a game you can just dip into for five minutes - it needs focus and attention, but I for one think the time is worth it :)

												This game was very difficult to get into at first.  I almost gave up on it, but I'm glad I didn't!  The depth to this game is amazing, and it will require some actual planning and strategy to build wealth and power.On the downside, starting as a new play is very intimidating.  There is very little in-game explanation of anything, and you have to learn a TON by trial and error.  On the upside, X3TC has a rich community and tons of resources in their forum.  I've spent a surprising amount of time outside of the game researching and planning what I'm going to buy and build.Great game, and you'll get a lot for your money, but you'll have to enjoy games with a long arc which require a lot of strategic planning - so it won't be for everyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This negative review is regrettable.  I had high hopes that this game was going to be a fun and interactive experience.  However, this game is an excercise in frustration for me.Don't get me wrong, I can understand why some people would really like it.I suppose, I'll do the typical pros versus cons style review and let you make your judgement.ProsDepth:  This game has so much depth and a real sense of immersion.  With innumerable ways to play.Customization:  Each ship's weapon loadout is customizable.Expansive:  Every system you enter is huge with many places to visit.  Players can even build their own space stations.ConsThis game does not respect your time:  Every system takes 5-10m to cross, with little-to-no interaction.  When you die, you are sent all the way out to the main menu to reload your save game, instead of given the option in-game.  Docking with stations takes 5-10m.  In six hours of gameplay, I have made little progress in any of my endeavors.  And, the smallest inkling of satisfaction for the time invested.The jump-drive is terrible:  This 'jump-drive,' accelerates time, but the ship must be on auto-pilot or it cannot make any maneuvers.In-game options:  The in-game options reset themselves for every new game you start.Long, useless tutorial:  The tutorial alone requires approximately 20m to complete and only teaches you basic flight controls.  Leaving the player to 'experiment' to figure out everything else.EXTREMELY steep learning curve: In the six hours I have played of this game, I have made little progress in understanding the economy and I am still finding new ship controls.Overall, I'm glad I bought this game on sale instead of paying full price.  However, I wish I could return it.

Don't give up on it right away, play around for the first hour or two, watch a tut on youtube because it's worth it.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												By the time of writing 70 hours and absolutely love this game so far! A big open world space simulator with absolute freedom to go wherever you want and do whatever you want. This game isn't for everyone though. There's a steep learning curve and you have to be patient because you start with nothing but a ship. I chose the merchant's path. Built my first two stations and have around 15 ships. Now it's just my trading empire I need :)

Posted: August 9, 2011
												A very challenging game at first. In the beginning, you will have ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA WHAT TO DO. That's what the internet is here for. Look up a tutorial, or ask a friend for some help. Once you get going, its a real fun game. I would suggest following the terran storyline first off, I never finished it. But doing it gives you some combat time, and it really helps you learn the basics.

Posted: June 5, 2012
												If you enjoy space sims and have the patience to get over the slower pace of the game and the high learning curve, I'd recommend giving X³ Terran Conflict a try. The sheer depth of simulation makes the game's universe truly come alive, from a dynamic supply/demand economy to factional wars being raged as you play, all simulated and not scripted. Be warned though, this game can be a real time-sink. I'm writing this review 20+ hours in and I feel like I've just scratched the surface.

Posted: May 20, 2012
												Not sure why it's taken me this long to put up a recommendation for this on Steam - especially since I essentially got three people to buy it because of me repeatedly telling them they should; followed by them enjoying the game - but oh well, I'll do one now, I guess!Anyway, if you've ever played a space sim (Freelancer's the main one that comes to mind) from years past, and would very much like more of that type of high-quality type of simulation, then look no further! Egosoft has done a very good job of making a (sometimes brutal) space simulation game where you can essentially do what you want in the universe; from being a mercenary fighting for those who pay well, to a trader seeking out the best deals, to a space station owner churning out resources for others to buy, to any and all of the above! (even more, really)X3: Terran Conflict really is a very good game, and one that you'll most certainly sink many hours into, providing you've got a joystick and are willing to learn.

Posted: March 26, 2013
												Not only is X strictly singleplayer (and hopefully staying that way forevermore), the community actually helps newcomers to the X Universe. They're one of the most mature gaming communities I've ever encountered. I thought those sorts of fanbases were a thing of the past, but the Egosoft forums (before the massive influx of newbies from X Rebirth came along) has proven me delightfully wrong.But, heh, back to reviewing the game itself. It's a space-sim. Trade, build, think, fight. Yes, think. It actually requires a brain unlike most games out there. Oh and the mod support, hell yes. If you have trouble, and as long as you're willing to, y'know, think for yourself, most everyone in the Egosoft modding forums are eager to assist.If you like games such as Sim City, then you'll still love the X series. I suppose you could call it Space Trading Empire Tycoon meets Wing Commander, but the entire series is much more than that.

Posted: October 2, 2014
												This game is incredible.  It has the feel of EVE but in a single player sandbox mode.  There are so many things to do in the game such as trading, exploring, the various mission system, and storylines.  Highly recommend this getting this if you enjoy space sims.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												The X series has been around for quite a while and with each iteration the scope and depth and quality has expanded. This however is not a pick up and play for 5 minutes kind of game. There is a vast universe to explore with multiple different races trading and fighting for control. You start out small just one ship among the many, but that is just the start. Trade, Fight, Capture Ships, Discover. Gain credits. Buy Ships. Upgrade. Build space factories. RULE THE UNIVERSE...eventually. like i said it all takes time, and death is always just in the next sector.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Super DEEP space sim, similar to the old Wing Commander Privateer, but with you controlling more than just your own ship.  While the game is obscure to just jump into, there are a number of great online video tutorials that can help you get started.  If you like SIM games (not just 4X games), this is definitely worth a try.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												Looking for an in-depth space sim where you'll spend hundreds, if not thousands of hours of your life on?  This game is for you.With tons of systems to explore, which are very lively and as well as unpredictable, you can decide what you want to become.  Would you want to be a hardcore space fighter destroying anything you see fit, or would you want to take the long simple route of starting your own trade empire, or you can do both.There are several main story campaigns as well, some that are extremely long and/or challenging, but finishing each of them can be very rewarding.  But since you can start doing those anytime, you'll probably be spending most of your time exploring and building up your trade empire first. :3

Posted: November 10, 2011
												I must admit, I was somewhat hestiant about whether or not I could recommend this game to others. Not for a lack of quality, but because I cannot say with any degree of certainty that the average gamer will enjoy this experience. If you are the sort of person looking to find a fast-paced, action-filled shooter, then this may not be the game for you. If, however, you are one who is truly passionate for incredibly immersive space simulators, and are willing to spend the time getting to know and unveiling the true beauty of the game, then Terran Conflict is for you. One of the greatest things about this game is how alive the universe truly feels. The hundreds of unique vessels you encounter throughout your travels are all part of a vast economic network comprised of several alien civilizations that span countless sectors. Your actions as you traverse this space will create tangible effects, thus making the construction of your interstellar empire immensly satisfying.

												Having killed off the Zerg and Protoss two X games ago, the Terrans start arguing over which of them has to build the Pylons.

Posted: August 16, 2012
												I'm not sure recommending this game is something I should do... I love it, and I hate it. I love the concept and the immense universe, I love the freedom it gives you and the ability to mod it. What I wish it had was a multiplayer component so I could share this world with someone.This game is like life. I have played it for a long time, but I still have no clue what its about or what I should do or even how to do it, but I do love it.

Posted: August 26, 2012
												If you have the time and patience, it can be a really great game. Space exploration, trading, pirates, lots of missions, build stations (and other things), and among all of that.. there is an extremely steep learning curve. The training you get isn't even enough to understand everything in this game.. you gotta teach yourself.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												By far one of my favorite space simulator games. With a huge, sprawling universe filled with various races and factions, and the ability to fly any ship, build any station, and automate all of this there is almost never a shortage of anything to do. On top of this, there is tremendous mod support, leading to hundreds of community mods, including a whole universe rewrite (new sectors, tens of new ships with improved graphics and effects, and a lot more). Would recommend installing the All-In-One pack from Egosoft before starting play, as it adds in some software for improved automation and a booster.

Posted: July 13, 2012
												This game has perhaps the highest learning curve ever.  With the most minimal of tutorials, I've heard someone say that if you're not completely lost for the first five hours, you were on the developement team.  With that being said, this is one of the deepest most engrossing gaming experiences I've ever had.  I've spent more hours than I'm comfortable saying on this game, I still lie awake at night thinking about what I'm going to do next in the game.  If you have the patience and drive to learn how to play this game, it will consume your life.  It is that awesome.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												I really enjoy X3TC and I'll try to explain why:X3TC is a massive game. There are 10 different races, which have 13 different ship classes, which have more than 100 different factories! There is a massive amount of weapons to chose from. There is diplomacy, piracy, illegal goods, asteroid mining, an economy of supply and demand and corporate armys. I've played roughly 280hours and I haven't finished all of the available quests and plots. It's totally up to you, what you want to be in this game: you don't HAVE to fight, nor do you have to be a CEO, to sucessfully finish the game. It's totally up to you and this really does add to the replayability. This may be why it's still so much fun!There's just endless stuff to do. I'm still all over the Wiki and egosofts page, looking stuff up. The learning curve may be a little steep, but it's definitely no EVE Online!Even though Steam Workshop is not implemented in this game, there still are heaps of mods for the game out there, on the developers web page and their forum. The community of X3TC is amazing and has created a massive amount of extra content for the game, even adding completely new content, ships, ect. There are also heaps of minor modifications which improve the gameplay. I have played around 270hours vanilla client: the game works just fine without mods!For those of you interested in combat, yes it's possible and it's more than just point and click. It's actually quite hard and you will die a lot, until you have a proper ship, and even then, it may not be so easy afterall. There is a lot of tactical depth to the game, as you can command different squads of smaller fighters, while you're in your capital ship, watching the scene and giving orders. Guns shoot in specific directions, so look out for angles where it can't shoot you. The battles are beautiful and especially the battles of larger ships never sease to amaze me! You may take over other ships, take their equipment and sell the rest. You may pirate merchants, steal their cargo and sell it. You may also place your orders and just watch the amazing scenes of destruction around you. There are endless possibilities of weaponry and ships of choice: there is no "best ship" with the "best equipment", you'll have to figure out which one works best in the situation you're in. There are however general guides on which set up works well, so you can get some kind of guideline to go by.Yes, there are many different screens and menus to click through, but they're pretty much straight forward and mostly for giving orders to your own and other ships, or buying stuff. Most of the games menus can be accessed through shortcuts, so if you use those, it's not so much menu-clicking afterall! I recommend giving it a try, because you'll see that the menus usually deal with the stuff that would take ages, if you had to do it yourself, so really they give you time to roam freely!A couple of sentences to those of you interested in trading and setting up a business! The very basics are: buy low, sell high. Place good investments and meet demands that aren't being met yet. There are automatic traders which you can order at some point. There are also other fellow traders out there, looking for a good deal too, so they might just beat you to it! Sooner or later, you'll have enough money to buy your own factories/mines and maybe even set up a whole business that refines your resources into more valuable goods for a better profit margin. You'll have to organise everything from the cargoships supplying any required resources to the price you want your product to be placed at. For an even higher profit margin, you can organise a merchant to sell your own products to the highest bidder. The economy is incredibly well made, in a way that you can actually flood a market and cause prices to drop, as well as increasing prices by withdrawing, like pirating the freighters of your fellow businessmen. But don't worry, there are enough possibilities for obtaining a reasonable profit, yet money is definitely not thrown at you.This game is "old", yes and there doesn't seem a lot of people about, still playing it. Why do I still enjoy it? First of all, the graphics are incredibly good, for a 2008 game and it's still looking very good for todays standards. It's no Crysis and for the shame of egosoft, I personally think it looks better than X:Rebirth, which I, at this point, do not recommend buying!  One last thing you should know about X3TC: it's a slow game. Your most used key will probably be "J", as that speeds up time, otherwise travelling and lots of other things may be very frustrating. The distances are immense and as I said, but it's no endless travelling and waiting. But watching X3TC gameplay videos may be very dull, depending on the player. That may lead to a wrong impression of the game, because it's definitely busier than, for instance, Civ5.If you want to try out the X Series, try Terran Conflict, or X:Albion Prelude. They're both older games, essentially the same with minor differences, but they still look good and give you hours of gameplay. I'd personally recommend X3TC, since I find the stock market in X3AP to be game breakingly easy, at supplying you with large amounts of cash. But that's just my humble opinion!X3TC is one of the few games that don't get too much attention, sadly. It's a great game and I've had many hours of fun and there's still more to come! Even after months of a break, I recently bought Skyrim, I came back to it. For me, that's a sign of a properly good game. If you've read this far, I suggest you giving it a try. As I said, the game is massive and it's difficult to provide an overview of a game of this scale!

Posted: May 5, 2014
												I recommend this game... but not for everyone.I would recommend this game to any fan of the space-sim genre (who has a LOT of time on their hands and is willing to learn) BUT... buyer beware, there are some major flaws (I will ellaborate) and it is almost a necessity to mod the game to make it accessible and playable.There is a MASSIVE learning curve (anyone who says otherwise is talking *&%$), I am about 200 hours into my first playthrough and I feel like I have barely scratched the surface of what you can actually do in this game. Any game with an instruction manual that is over 100 pages long is going to require some serious patience. I even found EvE-Online more accessible than X3TC. Some people will find these to be plus points but for those who want a game they can just pick up and play... buy something else. Don't listen to anyone who compares this to Freelancer (Freelance was much more of an arcade game), if you enjoyed Freelancer there is no guarantee you will enjoy this game.First I will list what I though were the good points :-Graphics are pretty good for a game of its age. -Reasonable sound with great music.-A HUGE universe to explore.-A plethora of different ships, space stations, weapons, ship equipment, etc. (the vast majority of which the player can own themselves).-A bustling trade universe with many resources and end products which the player can trade in.-Great sandbox feel to the game, you could play for hundreds of hours and build a huge trade empire or combat fleet without ever touching on a "Plot" mission.-A very helpful and dedicated fan base who are more than willing to help out new players (dont think i have ever seen the word "noob" on any forum/thread), there is a huge resource of info about the game on various websites/youtube and there is a large modding/scripting community.Now the not-so-good :-The game interface can be pretty cryptic and is not very intuitive at all. It took me a long time to figure it out (in fact I still dont think I have it figured out fully). A lot of the fans of the X series will praise the interface but I think they are comparing to previous X games (which must have had a truly aweful interface).-The AI can be pretty dumb, flying ships into stations or something simmilar. However i think this has been mostly sorted out in the later versions of the game.-Missions directives can sometimes be quite confusing and it is easilly possible for a player to accept a mission that they are vastly under-equiped for, which is just poor game design IMO.-Some of the plot mission requirements are absolutely insane and from what I have read, many players opt to mod the game to lower the requirements (because they really are that rediculous, requiring the player to amass huge amounts of resources) which feels a bit like cheating to me. But remember, you don't HAVE to do the plot (sandbox).-Very little in the way of in-game tutorials leaving the player to figure out most of it on their own. I for one, dont mind having to sift through the manual or read the wiki to figure stuff out, but for some this will be a deal-breaker.-The need to mod the game.... you really do have to. The vanilla game is sadly lacking in certain areas and without some of the mods the vanilla game feels like a beta.-The NPC voices are incredibly anoying!!!In conclusion this is a game with huge potential so long as you are willing to put in hundreds of hours of gameplay (its like having a second job!!). It can be very rewarding and incredibly frustrating at the same time. The interface can be very irritating at times but if you can get to grips with it, there is a lot of enjoyment to be had. If you are looking at buying this game I would highly recommend having a look at the available mods and what they do BEFORE you start playing, because some of the mods require you to restart the game from the beginning before they will take effect.A vast, deep game with huge potential so long as you are willing to put in the time and can get past the steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Forget the last installment (X:Rebirth). This is the absolute crown of the series.Amazing depth, complexity, moddability and visuals, this Ship of the line of the X-series puts you in a truly captivating and immersive universe for you to explore. I've spent countless hours back before on non steam version with simply exploring systems as I searched for lucrative trade opportunities and keeping an eye out for hostile presence on the scanners, but if you want to do mission, bounty hunt, build or pirate, you have all the opportunities.My favourite of the X series. The interface might be a bit intimidating first, but you can soon get used to it and it truly feels like a complex, scriptable ship computer, again adding a bit to the immersion and the tools it offers to the player in commands and mods are endless.

Posted: August 16, 2013
												This is a true Space Simulator, it has amazing depth and complexity and features that most space simulators lack, from capturing ships with marines, to making a commercial empire while using the money from it to fund a private fleet for your own purposes or sabotage rival merchants  in real time. One of the biggest features is responsive ai that truly think independently, if you attack their assets or blockade their freighters they will send a response fleet to deliver their message in fire and fury, or attack your own vessels and assets, they also develop stations and construct their own empires as you would too. the only dissavantages to this game lies in its complexity and its camera, this game is so complex that it can be very intimidating for casual rpg'ers and its camera is none to fancy either and very sticky, with only a first person view and a third person view that is also in only one angle (you cant move the camera) however because of this, dogfights and battles tend to be more advance as more precise ship controls add to the elements. All in all i give it a 8 out of 10 and so far is very fun ( i have done some backgroud research) for a single player game it is simply outstanding and surprising what it can offer.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												Deep and immersive.  The game will provide many, many hours of entertainment.  The combat is great, the in-game economy is very involved, and the ships are gorgeous.  What keeps this game from being perfect are the campaigns.  This game is near perfect and I'd recommend it to anyone.The learning curve is steep and less mature players may have a difficult time getting started.  This is a small note for me, after all, I came into this game with no experience in the genre and I loved it!Unfortunately, several of the plots, most notably the "Hub" plot, take so long that by the time you finish them, you really don't have much motivation to continue playing the game because there's nothing left to do.  At that point, you'll be super-powered and you'll have all the cash you could ever need - there are no challenges left to be conquered unless steam achievements are important to you.  Thus, any rewards you gain from said plot are basically worthless because you won't continue playing long enough to truly utilize them.

Posted: April 6, 2011
												This is a good, albeit slow-paced, sandbox space simulator with a fully realized intersteller supply-and-demand based business economy. X3 offers plenty of eye candy all around; its universe is a beautiful place. Follow the main story, or break away and come back to it as you please. Fully customize your starting ship(s) with upgrades to weapons, navigation, optics, etc. as you can afford them.  Work your way up in the corporate world by purchasing manufacturing spacestations, cargo vessels to transport goods and fighters to defend stations or escort vessels; build a financial empire, be your own Builderberg Group. Eventually, you can purchase an armada of capital ships and support vessels that you can use to supplement your firepower inside and outside of the main plot. You can helm any vehicle you purchase (provided you're close enough for a short spacewalk), and then, with upgradable ship computer software, issue orders to the rest of your fleets from the comfort of your captains seat. Maintain diplomacy with a variety of alien species, some of whom are mortal enemies, neutrals, allies, and still others who will eventually warm up to you after you invest some cash in their economies or shoot down enemies inside their sectors. Chilled out game-relaxing at times-that you can play with one hand on the mouse, or using the keyboard only, or both if you choose; it works however you want to play it. It's a complete change of pace from FPS games, and there can be long dull intervals between exciting firefights. Think of it as Elder Scrolls: Oblivion in space. Epic. Be who you want to be: Trader, Fighter, Fleet Commander, Pirate, Business Mogul. The choice is yours.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun to a degree... I have to say even for how old the game is at this part the graphics are great, HD great but good enough for a space game. Controls are great and even better with a joy stick.For everything great about the game the only real problem with this game i really have is it doesn't have much of a story or anything to really drive you forward outside of your want to get money, get bigger space ships, and basically making your own space empire in a sector you basically took over.Another problem is your all of your other ships controlled by the AI are just dumb. you will set up lets say 4 body guard ships and if they go fast well guess what they will either run into you or each other and blow up. considering how much money you have to put into a ship that is very hard on you and almost not even worth having them. 90% of the time i just go at it alone and just have them guard my transports...this makes it very hard to take on the many missions that pitch you against 7 to 8 ships at a time. But the last problem that is and isn't a problem, is how much time it takes to get around the map. They have a item you get and sometimes you have buy because it can be destoried by the way to speed up time. it doesn't make you go faster, it just makes time go by faster. it can take a lot of time getting anywhere...So there is a lot of good things about this game but those few things make this game hard to play and enjoy. But it is doable if you take the time, you can get Moddings that can make the game more enjoyable so have fun.

Posted: April 13, 2014
												A truely brilliant game! Spend the time to research and learn how to play it. Once you understand it you'll have a lot more fun and spend a lot of time playing. One of the best space sims around. One of the things I love is the choice. 												It takes a team of over 2000 programs at a big name company up to 2 years to make a decent game. Posted: October 8, 2016
												6 out of 10You get to build a space empire.  Who doesn't want to build a space empire?  Sadly though the game has some buggy bits that undermine its brilliance.You fly a space ship of your choice while building a trade fleet, gigantic space factories and armadas of fighters, frigates and destroyers. The good: 1. You get to build a space empire 2. Vast space environment.  Many factions, ships, factories and goods to master. 3. Friend or enemy?  You choose. The bad: 4. No real storyline. 5. There are many useful scripts to automate your space fleet but somehow they fall short of what you really want. 6. Within more than 100 hours I have really scratched the game's surface.  It really takes a huge amount of time to get anywhere. 7. Running your space empire becomes very tedious. The ugly: 8. Automated ships have horrendous collision detection.  I have lost far more ships to collisions than to enemy fire. I feel that a modern version of X3 could be an amazing game.  This game however never delivers a climax, it is a long drawn out "nice" experience.

Posted: October 16, 2016
												I absolutely love this game. It took me a while to figure out how to get a hold of the game, but after I read a quick guide I got the hang of what to do. The large variety of ships to pilot and different styles of game play you can take is what makes this so great. Want to buy and sell, do it, get a ship big enough. Find yourself wanting to partake in some fighting, get a fighter or build the largest fleet that you can and destroy whatever you want. I need to rack more hours in these game because it always keeps me highly entertained and involved in the story and allows me to create my own path. Yes, it takes time to get into it, but it is well worth the time if you enjoy space games. I particularly enjoy the fact that my Intel HD 4400 graphics on my i7 computer can run this without lag and take this game like a champ where most games can’t.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Massive Space Sim.Go from nothing in a tin can to massive trading empire.Start with no guns, end up with carrier battle groups at your command.This technological terror does more than kill planets and fleets, it allows you to annihilate entire races and build manufacturing complexes to supply your endless thirst for combat. You can pilot a single seat space superiority fighter or command a warship capable of laying waste to an entire sector singlehandedly.This ain't like dusting crops boy. There is however a steep learning curve, and the more you fight and defeat an enemy the higher your combat rating gets, so it will not possible to continue treating the game like a space combat sim. The enemy forces thrown at you during missions will evolve to meet your combat rating. The more you kill the harder it gets to stay a fighter jock. Eventually you have to become a fleet commander just to survive a fight. In so doing, the bigger your fleet gets and the more cash and equipment you will need to outfit it. This is where trading and empire building becomes more than just an entertaining tangent.Play the game, become your own nation, do as you please because you can gain full control of the gate network and your own sectors....and the Paranid will still insult you.

												My Experience So Far:Day 1: Chased down a crate 80km away while moving at ~80 m/s (almost 17 minutes) and then had to go back to the flight instructor (another 17 minutes). I'll take on these four pirates. Nope! I'm not getting good....Day 5: Spend 80% of my money on a trade ship and get him to do remote trade runs while I fly around in a scout. He gets killed before making back 10% of the cost. I'm broke....Day 8: Got a big ship with big guns. Installed shields, went to battle. Got wrecked. Had wrong shields installed. Still not good at the game.Day 9: Accepted a Very Hard combat mission to assassinate a guy in a Corvette class ship while flying in a scout. Opened comms with my Corvette and had him warp in, wrecked faces earned 2 million credits in 2 minutes.

You can pilot a single seat space superiority fighter or command a warship capable of laying waste to an entire sector singlehandedly.This ain't like dusting crops boy. There is however a steep learning curve, and the more you fight and defeat an enemy the higher your combat rating gets, so it will not possible to continue treating the game like a space combat sim. The enemy forces thrown at you during missions will evolve to meet your combat rating. The more you kill the harder it gets to stay a fighter jock. Eventually you have to become a fleet commander just to survive a fight. In so doing, the bigger your fleet gets and the more cash and equipment you will need to outfit it. This is where trading and empire building becomes more than just an entertaining tangent.Play the game, become your own nation, do as you please because you can gain full control of the gate network and your own sectors....and the Paranid will still insult you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												X3: Terran Conflict (and the X3 series in general) is difficult to write a recommendation for because I'm not really sure why I love it. In fact, every time I try to talk about it, I inevitably get round to a laundry-list of complaints, particularly about the interface or the AI. But paradoxically, not being sure why I love it is exactly the reason I love it, and the reason X3:TC is my single most-played game.I've never been a fan of the nostalgist's lament that games were better in the old days, but one thing that a lot of modern games are is predictable. Sure, I like them, but I know exactly why I like them, because they've been risk-aversely designed to be obviously enjoyable. X3:TC is enjoyable, but not obviously so, and in that, it recaptures some of the magic of an older generation of games.If you like games where polish has been sacrificed for depth and vastness, and games where your own personal goals become more important than the embedded storyline, then definitely check out X3:TC. Be warned, though: it will eat your life.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2011
												  Much better UI makes a diamond in the rough of a series finally polished enough to be accessible. This game has more depth and attention to detail than any other sand box game , space or otherwise I have ever seen. What was once a series that demanded hours of research to fly from A to B , is now a beatiful game that begs you to make it yours and to explore and to care about it and to loose hours and hours of your time. But I did my research a plenty trying to play the others, I went into this with a solid knowledge base. That its improvements to the UI was just enough to get me to tollerate its still rather complex interface. But at least I can say that for the most part its interface is complex out of necessity, for all that it lets you do and command, rather than out of a masochist love for obfuscation and ellusiveness.  Just be warned this is by no means an easy game to get started in, and I highly recommend printing out or reading one of the MANY "noob" tutorials out there.

number of helpful: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												If you are a space sim fan and have run out of titles to choose from, then this game is worth a go. There is a lot of depth and many different ships to fly within a huge open universe. That being said, there is a huge learning curve to go with the depth. I found myself browsing the web for answers on how to do even the simplest of things far more often than I would have liked.  The tutorial is...well, you on a search engine because the developer felt as though only people who had played their previous entries would be playing this game.  The graphics are nice but there is no getting out to explore planets or space stations. You are limited to being in or around a ship throughout the entire game. In fact, you will never be planetside at all.  The AI is horribly broken to the point that it could frustrate Ghandi, assuming that Ghandi would have been a video game nerd (I'm not sure he'd be a space sim fan if he was), which constantly gives you the ultimatum of either losing large amounts of money or reloading your previous save. Choosing either option causes you to feel as though you have recieved the raw end of the deal since you will never get back the time spent. If you are not like Ghandi the space sim fan and prefer action to trade then you again shouldn't bother as you will indeed be bored. There is action but there is far more travel-time than action and when it does break out, the enemy A.I. is not very bright and the outcome is based on a numbers game (who has more firepower). I personally don't mind travel-time in a space sim game but I'm sure it is only because I like the genre and the exploration that comes with it as opposed to enjoying this particular franchise. Sadly, there is no cockpit view to enjoy the exploration with and the camera is rather limited as well. There is a couple of outside views available but one of those views cannot be used to navigate intuitively and the other view is a camera stuck directly behind your burners with no allowance for deviation so you cannot really see your ship anyhow. It's possible there is an option somewhere to move this camera but it seems that will be another research topic for when I play the game next...which would be whenever I'm bored of poking myself in the eye with a stick.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												This of the bunch really stands out from the rest, not only for the comprehensive and very fluent controls, but for the general feel and charm. It makes me laugh at how people relate the X series to Elite Dangerous and Star Citizen, basing it off of X-Rebirth, the casual bad seed of the bunch. Though Elite Dangerous has a very quirky and uneventful feel to it, it's just as linear as the newest addition to the series, giving much reason for bashing. Star citizen? Hype train with little to show. With almost 37 hours in the first week, I am happy to say that I have only barely scratched the surface! I would recommend this to anyone who would like to learn the X series, giving you the ability to jump in, and, (with the help of reading the controls menu, which seems like a foreign concept to some) I was able to learn my simple functions. Mechanics came logically afterwards, using a click on something before attempting to use corresponding hotkeys. Just don't forget to save! In a world rich with lore, content (every ship/carrier/station can be owned and/or piloted), mystery, and countless hours of unique experience. Oh, and not to mention; It's cheaper than the competition~Happy voyaging :3

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												X3: Terran Conflict put one, very important thing into perspective for me: space is astronomically huge. (Pun so very much intended.) It also taught me something very important: it takes way too damned long to fly anywhere in space. Let’s do this.I – Story [5/10]X3: Terran Conflict is an open world, simulation game from Egosoft. There are multiple stories for the player to choose from, but I will be dealing specifically with the first one, “Terran Defender”.The player assumes the role of a Terran pilot who is out on a routine patrol in the solar system when, suddenly, they are summoned to aid in a battle at Neptune. Xenon pilots, using special beacons, were able to jump deep into the system; bypassing the usage of a jumpgate. During the ensuing chaos, a drone steals information from the Terran station at Neptune and delivers it to an Argon ship near Pluto. After the battle, the player is given the task of investigating the hostile activity of the Xenon, who are suspected to be under the influence of a hitherto unknown source.Xenon and various pirate factions are discovered to be coordinating raids on ships for valuable resources. New ships begin to appear, which resemble Terraformers (Boron warships). The player assists in the delivery of Terraformer wreckage to Terran scientists who are able to deduce that the new ships are counterfeits based heavily upon commonwealth technology.Robert Pearle (an undercover Terran operative) has information concerning the origins of the new Terraformer ships, but he has been taken into custody by Argon forces. The player meets up with a fellow Terran agent, Patricia Heywood, and the two set off to rescue Pearle from the Argons. Following Pearle’s extraction, he accompanies the player on a mission to Split Space where it is rumored that the new Terraformers are being built. A mobile factory is discovered and taken by Terran forces and several Split scientists are taken prisoner as well. During interrogation, one of the scientists mentions the name Aldrin. (Aldrin was a Terran colony that was established long before the Terraformer War. The colonists at Aldrin managed to shut down their jumpgate and protect their Terraformers from the software error. Aldrin had been presumably lost during the war.)The Terrans launch an offensive; reverse-engineering a jump beacon to get a fleet to Aldrin. A fleet of Xenon ships joins the battle against the Terrans, defending the Terraformers. A boarding party successfully takes control of the Terraformer CPU ship and the player is tasked with escorting Aldrin dignitaries to the Earth Torus, thereby opening Earth to the player.Had I played the previous games in the series (which I was unaware was a series until I started into this review) I probably would have enjoyed the story more than I did. That being said, the story was still okay (and very reminiscent of the opening mission of the first Mass Effect).II – UI [7/10]Once I figured the user interface out (for the most part) it was a great system for the game. There was a “tutorial” (for lack of a better word), but it was not all encompassing. I felt a bit on my own to figure out the more advanced functions of the game. There was no minimap, which put quite a handicap on navigating. Aside from this though, the user interface, as I said, worked great for the game.III – Gameplay [7/10]Gameplay in X3:TC was really fun. Learning how the UI worked took some time, but the gameplay itself, was very unique. It is all first-person, whether you’re nestled safely inside your vessel or ejecting into the merciless void of space. It was a great way to explore and I sincerely hope we see things like this much more in games that are yet to be released.My biggest complaint about the gameplay, however, is that (aside from combat) it is incredibly slow paced. If travel time had been done in relation to how long most people can stare into the abyss, it would have been okay. With the exception of the Grinch and sociopaths the world over, travel times can become extremely boring.IV – Content [10/10]There is a truly massive amount of content in X3:TC. There is a huge universe to explore (and exploring it fully could very well take you the amount of time it would take a real astronaut), tons of missions, over 100 ships, ship classes, and weaponry. If you can stay interested long enough to discover it all, more power to you.V – Visual [7/10]The graphics in X3:TC are decent. Taking into consideration that immense scale of the game, the graphics are about what you’d expect. While they’re not bad, they’re not outstanding.VI – Audio [5/10]I was rather unimpressed with the music of X3:TC. The soundtrack can often make or break a game (or salvage it from a gruesome end) but the music felt uninspired and pumped full of space-y noises. The sound effects weren’t bad and the voice acting was alright as well.VII – Overall [6.8/10]Overall, X3: Terran Conflict is an alright game. I didn’t like it as much as the rating I gave it, but, that’s that.

												This game has some serious balance issues.  You will start off easy enough, but not have any missions except to track down criminals or patrol sectors. Frequently you can visibly see the ship disappear.Game pace is way to slow.Recommended only if you are willing to download mods to fix the problems.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												This game has a great concept but poor execution. You have to go several menus deep to do most things, and I find myself spending most of my time repeating the same series of clicks over and over again. Maybe there is a better way to do it, but the game gives you no help in finding out what that might be. I watched several videos, and read tutorials online before playing, and even then I was expecting a steep learning curve. Which is fine. That's not the issue, the issue is the poor design of the game. The game gives you the option to trade lots of different goods, but in reality you can only trade energy cells and ore at the start. The others never vary enough in price to make them worth trading. The "dynamic" trade system results in the AI traders contently supplying factories with everything they need so the price never changes. The result is far from dynamic.I found my greatest goal in the game was to get an automated trader so I wouldn't have to do the mind numbing, and painfully slow trading myself. You know something is wrong when the goal of playing a game is to make it so you don't have to play the game.Another guide I read said you can build cash with missions. So I tried that. Except when you start out you can't do most missions. My slow trading ship can't do the trade missions fast enough. My discover can't haul enough, or fight well enough. A lot of missions require special equipment. So you fly around to 5 sectors looking for 1 mission you can actually do, then make a few thousand or tens of thousands or credits. I don't mind low rewards starting off, or hard to complete missions. The thing that gets me is having to tediously check 10-20 missions before you can find 1 you like. And it's not like you can fly into a sector and access all of the missions available in an quick, easy way either, no just get ready to mindlessly click through more menus.  Even with all of that, the game has potential, and I can see where it could be fun once you get the hang of it. But if you don't have hours and hours to sink into a game, and a lot of patients to slog through the learning curve, you're going to get frustrated with this game. Maybe once you're an expert the game is fun enough that you can ignore the poor deign, but I can't.

												No disappointments.  I was looking for an immersive single player space game, and X3 completely delivers.  The universe is huge - and there is a custom mode that somewhat randomizes the game, although it disables some key quests, so I haven't tried it.  Even without that, I have hundreds of hours logged and still haven't explored all the systems.Things missing from the game that would have improved it: customizable ship designs (you can only customize the amount of shields and weapons, but not the speed/acceleration/weight/etc).  Even without that, just getting the weapons you want manufactured and configuring a ship, fleet, or economic infrastructure gives plenty to keep track of.The tone of the game is dry - it's a German, serious Space Odyssey.  If I'd bought this when it first came out, I'd have shelved it, because the quests are almost impossible to figure out.  But now there are loads of tutorials online (both videos and forum posts) that make the game accessible.5 stars.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I played X2 and couldn't get into it. This one (which I've played just a little during the free weekend) is much more user-friendly. It's more complex than Galaxy on Fire (one of my favorite arcade-y space games), but there's an intriguing depth to the gameplay. If you're willing to put in some work and want to feel like you're really in an enormous galaxy of galaxies, check it out.---- EDIT ----After playing some more, I've decided that this game simply isn't for me. Moving around is slow (even when the acceleration SETA active), and navigation is pretty complicated. Worst of all -- the game only saves when you dock at a station, so after I spent 20 minutes chasing a pirate through four systems, his buddies killed me and I had to start all the way back at the first system. Maybe I've become spoiled by modern autosave features, or maybe I just prefer a more arcadey style. It's possible that I'll come back and give this one another try, but for now I'm going back to GoF.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Id love to say this game hooked me the first 5 minutes of playing.id love to say that this game is breathtakingly gorgeous.id love to say this game has some of the best space combat ive ever seen in any game, EVER.But i cant, because it doesnt. I can see how alot of people love this game, as it does have A TON of AWESOME stuff.love space? check.love great design? check.love no tutorial at all? check.Love a difficulty curve the size of foocking jupiter? check..Love a game whose controls are even more confusing than some modern flying simulators? CHECK...LOVE HUGE CRASHES THAT ERASE ALL YOUR FOOCKING SAVE PROGRESS 10 TIMES?!?!?! MOTHER FOOCKING CHECK!!!seriously though this game is awesome! i loved playing the first few days of it, but the thing is... during all of that, the one HUGE thing that i ABSOLUTELY DESPISE about this game? Traveling. It took me 2 days to get to the point where i could go much faster, or even instant traveling. Im glad its in the game, but seriously? Give this to me IMMEDIATELY. Do you know how many times i just sat back and waited 5 minutes to get from point a to point b? point a being maybe... 30Km away? thats the shortest distance btw. Ive had to travel up to 130Km away. Which means a total of 15 minute wait times... then when i get there, i may just have to wait another 10 for anything to actually happen... youre joking right? thats 25 minutes just to do ONE step. Of a beginning mission. One that has 15 steps... Oh good god...see why thats annoying?? dont get me wrong, i LOVE this game. It did get me hooked, but it took so LONG for me to get hooked... A game should be keeping me up to 2 am in the morning wanting just to do that one last step to a mission, just to find out theres two more steps, then staying up all night to finish it. But instead this game seems to want its begining to be the exact OPPOSITE of that. Which is saddening... This game is not all like that. Power through the begining as fast as possible and you get to the meat of the game.If anything im writing this as a warning to those who are just starting. Be ready to work your A$$ off to get to the actual begining of the game, and kick major xenon booty.Other than that, this game is damn near flawless. 8.5/1014/space    would nap between travel times again.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												I remember in my youth days playing the first ever game of X series (can't remember the name). It was awesome in its own way. It had an open world, trading aspect, dogfight, construction and an interesting plot. It buried into my mind as one of these games that kept one coming back.Several years later we got X3, which brought back memories and made me glee with expectations. Unfortunately I was deeply disappointed.One would expect that after so much time the series would improve significantly and draw some of the best solutions from other successful games. This here has not happened. It seems the game have stopped mentally in early 2000 but went on graphically to current gen. The world is VAST, gigantically OPEN, enormously FREE, pleasingly NEAT, and you are free to do as You please, in every aspect of this word. But before You do, there is a discouraging amount of things You first need to learn.One would expect to learn some basics of trading, exploring, upgrading, before even trying to comprehend the advanced forms of play. This here does not happen. What You're introduced to, is bare basics of ship control, and that's all. Looking at key configuration I had the feeling that someone outsourced tutorials to a player that had the game for 30 minutes. You're just thrown into the universe and be like "oh, You're here, follow me into this sector we've got some bad guys to kill". That's just an insignificant fraction of what the game has in store.X3 has almost nothing to offer in terms of introducing You into the world, apart from opening cinematic, and because of that it is unenjoyable from the beginning. You ask what's later? I don't know - I've been disappointed by game design to the point that I didn't want to find out. And believe me, I tried two times already in span of 2 years.There are other games worth Your time in terms of space exploration, trading, fights and empire building. Games like EVE, Freespace, Freelancer...IF You have time - take it at Your own risk. Otherwise - seek other solutions.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I was really close to give this game a YES, but there are few things that stopped me from doing it. First of all, the game has great potential, but execution is a bit lacking.First thing - the on board computer - it's driving me insane! I don;t know who came up with the idea that people will love hearing the emotionless voice reading over and over THE SAME GOD DAMNED SENTENCE n times in a row every time you click something. You click a station? Mining facility is bla bla bla... you want to sell the meat to the weapon factory? Of course, but let me sing you the song of my people! "The small sidearms factory produces[...]" emmm, thank, I just wanted to sell the meat... "The blabla meat steak is a nutrishious".To make things worse, you can disable all voice or none. Had I played this game any longer, I would have gone mad and started hearing those voices in my head...Next thing is the interface - it's not bad per se, it's just a bit confusing at first (took me about an hour to learn how to pilot the ship as all the controls are described in relation to joystick or a pad - but playing it with mouse and keyboard is actually good, but takes time getting used to it.Newbie friendly? Nope. Here, pick a starting game - we won't tell you what which one exactly gives so have fun guessing.I picked the humble merchant and from what I read online it is the best start.The game takes ages to start - for hours you just fly from one station to another buying and selling - looks like a wasted time to me. If you are a fighter pilot who just rushes from place to place to shoot things it's probably fun, but if you visit the same station every 10 or so minutes... "The asteroid mining facility" Aaagh, the voices returned!I'll probably grind it some more and se if I can get a decent profit to build up a small cargo fleet and set it to be automatic so that I could focus on other things, but so far, the voices alone are a reason to avoid this game.Did I mention the voices?EDIT - before someone rages - I disabled the voices - all of them, but it's removing the useful announcements as well as the info spam

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												I've now played enough to know that although this game is better than X3:Reunion, the interface is still poorly designed and they've made it even more annoying, hard as that may be to believe. So it's still a game for people who have a lot of patience, who don't mind doing a lot of external research about things that should be in-game, and are satisfied playing poorly designed games with lousy user interfaces that go out of their way to waste the gamer's time. The good:Much better than X3:Reunion. A lot of the issues with that game were resolved here.The bad:Autopilot. At least in X3:Reunion is worked. Here, it doesn't. Which means that as you wait for your ship to crawl across the screen, even with a 10x speed-up (assuming you have it installed on a ship - WHY would it not be part of the game rather than having to be installed on each and every ship??), you can't trust the autopilot to do it right. At least in X3:Reunion I could read a book while waiting. With X3:Terran Conflict, you have to babysit the bloody thing all the time. So not only do they waste my time, they've made it so that I can't do anything ELSE while they're wasting it.The more bad:flight mechanics. The usual rant about THIS IS SPACE DARNIT!  It's not "3D cars in mud". If I stop my engine, I shouldn't just stop dead. I shouldn't have to loop around to get at someone behind me, I should just be able to kill my engine and turn around, still moving in the same direction I was moving in earlier. I'll put up with a lot of "let's play fast and loose with reality" for a game, but that one issue with space games is something I'll never accept. Freelancer got it right. So far I've not found another that has done so.The ugly:Nothing major so far. However, the game seems to revel in wasting the time of the player.  Where "waste of time" involves making me spend real, irreplaceable time doing things that end up having zero impact in the game, either because you have to reload or just accept that you've just spent the last 20 minutes for nothing. Over and over again.Examples:-- Still incredibly annoying, especially early game, as they make you pay (a lot) for the ability to save without docking to a station. This means that, early game, when you're weakest, you're having to start from much further back JUST as you thought you'd finished.  Once you can afford the "save any time" it gets easier. Until then, expect to be doing a lot of swearing. Or a lot of docking and saving, which is a massive time waster, especially on longer "timed" missions. -- There are a lot more locals than in X3:Reunion, which means that when you take on a mission that requires you to fight someone else, more than half the time someone else will kill them for you, which wastes your time because they only count the LAST shot, not the total damage you did. So you bring then down to near zero and some local asshat pots the final shot in for you, aborting the mission and wasting all the time you spent doing it so far.-- The autopilot in X3:Reunion only killed me once. That has changed in X3:TC, and the autopilot now will regulary attempt to ram you through a solid surface. Since ships that can take large amounts of weapons damage disintegrate at the slightest bump in this game, this, again, wastes time.-- Don't bother with "covert missions". They seem to be bugged. No matter what distance you follow (5/10/15/20/25) you'll either be too close, or you'll lose them. Another waste of time.Conclusion:Waste of time, highly annoying, and just too many issues for me to be able to kick back and enjoy it. Still looking for a decent "space sim" game in the Freelancer model. Still waiting.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												note: i played about 40 hours of Albion Prelude before trying the Terran Conflict version, when i realised this is just the same type of game, Albion Prelude is just some sort of DLC ! so this review counts for BOTH or better ALL ot the X-games.i got 3 words for this type of games: boredom in spaceWhat comes next is only MY PERSONAL OPINION about this game, and you might want to agree or disagree with me, that's fine, but leave your comments for yourself please if you want to rant against MY OPINION, ok? Thanks in advance.There are some pro's in this game, i have to admit, but there are just too many cons that made me stop 'playing' this 'game' :1. everything takes way too much time, you can't accomplish anything in under 100 hours of gameplay; that is 2 or more whole WEEKS of worktime in your job! so i assume that most people who play this game are either a) unemployed or b) have no real life (no offense) or c) are retired and have alot of time on their hands2. Interface is really bad, overly complicated and takes many hours to get used to; it feels like i am back to college trying to get a degree in spacetrading/spacenavigation... that is in my opinion not fun, but WORK, and i am here to have FUN, not work, because it's supposed to be a GAME, right?3. for a spacesim, it's more then unrealistic: you jump lightyears over lightyears in a matter of seconds, but the space you work in ones you arrive is about 120km in diameter only! makes no sense to me, sorry... i don't even want to talk about how long it takes to get from one gate to the next one, even with 6x timespeeds (called SETA here). oh and then you have to 'explore' those sectors first? haha... that would be ok if it's space that belongs to another race, but the terrans and argons should know from the start where their planets are right? i get it, all those things are there so it can keep you busy, 'exploring' """new""" planets... problem is, they are already there when you started the game, so it's only new to YOU, right? kills any immersion for me to be honest.4. Jumpdrives need energycells so you can use them... are we in the 21st century? never heared of any spacegame or sci-fi series before that you need a f... battery to use a jumpdrive device of some sort that brings you halfway across the universe... it this a TESLA Demeter or what? Don't tell me this game wants to be environment-friendly! LOL5. Boredom in space for me is this: for about 3 minutes of action you need hours of preparation sometimes, and the rewards you get are often far worse then the cost. It may be me, but that's just not fun, is it? It's like going 1 step forward and 2 steps back...Ok there are mods out there that can solve many of those problems, BUT i just don't have the patience any more to deal with installing those mods and hope they work properly so you can finally, hopefully enjoy a game and hope that it doesn't crash BECAUSE of those mods! There is even a mod that removes the jumpdrives out of the fighters completely, so you can not use them anymore with them! REALLY?This game has a huge fanbase (again i think it shows the actual unemployment rate we have in the country - j/k hehe), so there are a LOT of mods out there, but so many, it's a) hard to find the latest version that works with your game and/or other modsb) the links to them don't work any more because they are too old and the files got removedc) the time you need to read through all these forum posts to find the things you are looking for.... you get the ideaThere are so many more issues with this game that i could go on and on, but i don't want to waste any more of my time for that, so for players who consider buying this game, be warned: before you start to play this game do these things first:a) quit your jobb) end any existing relationships (if you had some before)c) get yourself a supply of food and water for several months so you don't have to leave your home EVERd) get yourself a supply of antidepressiva or other drugs that can keep you happy while reading all the information you can/must get about this game, because you will NEED to read alot before you start to understand what this game is all about (alcohol works too)e) be prepared to take a test after you read through all the material about this game (test will be playing the game itself)f) hide all items you could use to commit suizide ones you realise how much time you wasted for nothingg) find the uninstall buttonGood thing i bought this whole X-game stuff on sale for like 14 bucks, so it's not too big of a loss to me financially... i just want my wasted time back please ;-)

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												About this game and its issues..This game is not multi-threaded so hangs off a single core, this causes lag and slowdown for many people once you get into larger ship battles (you will have to play probably 100 hours at least to get that far unless you research the x3 forums for hours for exploits and shortcuts). Even in larger sectors with many stations things are choppy to begin with.Missions are often unclear, boring & take very long periods of time to complete so you will need loads of patience.The economy is largely broken, your ai ships will fly into station often if you are in the same region of space and there is a ton of menus to navigate to do ANYTHING. Creating and managing stations is simply a badly implemented horrible exasperating experience.AVOID.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												TL;DR;-Slow game pace (Even for a space game I consider the pace too slow)-instanced space pockets = Vast universe now apparently (Wth are people smoking)-Game mechanics don't make sense (Repairing costs more than buying a new ship)-Misions are too random and unbalanced meaning you wont be able to do most of them.-Cannot save game on the fly, you must dock which is a tedious task (even with autopilot).-Buggy autopilot, basic controls, camara and UI makes this game less appealing.I heard someone say on a forum something like "The game is long, not slow". That of course is wrong. Skyrim is long. This game IS SLOW.The game like many other space games fail on one simple thing; Travel time. Due to this, you spend about 90% of your time traveling from destination X to Y to Z. And in this game it does little to take away that factor. You may as well be watching a screen saver. You cannot save the game until you are docked. Which only reduces yet again the pace of the game. If you dont save your game, you littlerly have to start again if/when you die. This means, yes, more traveling and doing the same♥♥♥♥♥♥you just did an hour ago. (Oh and docking aint fun in this game, there is no "click and dock" you have to either wait for the slow♥♥♥♥♥♥autopilot or manually dock yourself)The game is not vast despite what you might hear. You go from sector to sector via warp gates. It's just a load of instances linked together. Oh and you cannot interact with planets in any way. They are just background art.The controls, camera and UI are very basic. Giving commands to your other ships is executed poorly. You can give limited quick commands when targeting other ships (Or rather I should say command) which is attack. Thats it. The autopilot is also buggy, a lot of the time it will just throw you about makiing you puke from motion sickness.Some other things that don't make much sense: its cheaper to buy a new ship than to repair the one you have (And yes ships cost A LOT). Misions are completely randomized meaning that you wont be able to do like 90% of them near the start of your game. They are also unremarkable from what I've seen; "Do this and get credits" everytime.Glad I tried this game on free weakend. I won't be buying it and will not recomend it to anyone, one of the most boring and unbalanced space games I have played to date.
